title: How to Run Command Prompt Commands from a Windows Shortcut

steps.title: Right-click a blank area of the desktop.
steps.content: Right-click a blank area of the desktop. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Type %comspec% /k into the text box.
steps.content: Type %comspec% /k into the text box. The -k flag keeps the command prompt window open after the command is run. You can remove the flag if you prefer the window closes right away.

steps.title: Type the command you want to run.
steps.content: Type the command you want to run. Whatever command you type after %comspec% /k is the one that will run when you double-click this shortcut. For example: [2] X Research source %comspec% /k ping www.google.com will ping www.google.com when you double-click the shortcut. %comspec% /k sfc scannow will scan all protected system files when you double-click the shortcut.

steps.title: Enter a name for the shortcut.
steps.content: Enter a name for the shortcut. This is the text that will appear under the icon. For example, if the shortcut pings Google, you could type ping google .

steps.title: Click Finish.
steps.content: Click Finish . The shortcut is now on your desktop.

steps.title: Double-click the shortcut to run the command.
steps.content: Double-click the shortcut to run the command. The command prompt window will appear, and you’ll see your command running.

steps.title: Create a desktop shortcut for the command.
steps.content: Create a desktop shortcut for the command. A keyboard shortcut is a combination of keyboard keys you press to run a command or program. To create one for a command line command, make sure you’ve already created a desktop shortcut. [3] X Research source Keyboard shortcuts will follow the format Ctrl + Alt + [other key] . You’ll be able to choose a letter, number, or punctuation key as the “other key.” For example, b , . , 3 .

steps.title: Click Properties.
steps.content: Click Properties . The “Shortcut” tab of the Properties screen will appear.

steps.title: Press a letter, number, or punctuation key.
steps.content: Press a letter, number, or punctuation key. The text box will fill with the entire shortcut using the key you press. For example, if you press p , the text in the box will change to Ctrl + Alt + P . If you create multiple keyboard shortcuts, make sure not to use the same key twice. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Click OK.
steps.content: Click OK . You’ll now return to the desktop.

steps.title: Press Ctrl+Alt+[other key] to run the command.
steps.content: Press Ctrl + Alt + [other key] to run the command. The command prompt window will appear, running the command you set up in the desktop shortcut .
